App description:
** AGENT, YOUR EXPLOSIVE, FINAL MISSION 'OPERATION: DEATH ENGINE' IS NOW AVAILABLE **

I Expect You To Die is a virtual reality puzzle game that places you in the well-polished shoes of an elite secret agent. You must attempt to survive deadly situations in immersive and dangerous locales. 

Complete each operation using problem-solving skills and wits oh, and the power of telekinesis that all our agents are equipped with. Use it and whatever resources you can find to escape each situation... or die trying.

Privacy Policy

I Expect You To Die (IEYTD) is a virtual reality (VR) escape-the-room puzzle game that lets you step into the world of an elite secret agent. IEYTD is intended to entertain. This Privacy Policy describes how we use, share, and protect information that we collect from players of IEYTD.

COLLECTION OF INFORMATION

We may collect anonymized information from your play of IEYTD. Please note, IEYTD does not collect the players name, physical address, contact information, or any geolocation information.

USE OF INFORMATION

We use the information that we collect to analyze and improve our game and support the internal operations of IEYTD. We aggregate all information collected so that it cannot be used to identify any particular player.

CHANGES TO THIS PRIVACY POLICY

We may revise this Privacy Policy, for example, to reflect changes in the law, our practices, or the features of IEYTD. These changes will be effective immediately upon posting. As a result, you should periodically review the Privacy Policy so that you are up to date on our most current policies and practices. By playing IEYTD, you agree to the terms and conditions of this Privacy Policy, and, by continuing to play IEYTD after changes have been made, you agree to the changes.

STILL HAVE QUESTIONS?

If you have any questions or concerns regarding this policy, please contact us at:

YellowSh0rtBusA day ago
Honest Review

This was a fun little experience with lots of clich Bond moments. I mean this high praise. I absolutely loved the intro sequences art style!

The game is overall great and you should definitely pick it up. I was never bored and enjoyed each mission. I never felt too challenged, but maybe having the player quickly progress past their failures was the intent of the developers.

My only problem is just as the game felt like it was getting good it was over. Its really the only reason for 4 instead of 5 stars. I was starting to really get into this universe and it was over. Sure, I could go back and try to get all the trophies but the end of each mission is the same. Maybe they have more plans for this game. Its certainly setup to scale easily, but I was just hoping for a little more play time.

Either way, dont let this one slip past you. Its a fun, lighthearted game that almost anyone would enjoy.

That combined with the incredible detail of each scene (readable notes/newspaper, many interactive objects, even ones that are just for fun) really help it feel like an actual virtual world.

The puzzles are fun, and make you think quickly which can pump your adrenaline. The narrator guy is pretty funny.

I give it 4.5/5 is because I find it very tedious to repeat certain actions 100 times, as you restart each level when you die. I must have spent at least 15 minutes pouring stupid fuel into an engine because I kept dying on a certain level. I personally think the better solution would have been to allow a continue or a limited amount of continues per level try. I just don't see the benefit or point of having to restart the level over and over.

If this were fixed it would be an easy 5 stars. Easily one of the most polished titles on Quest.

There are some cool end-game features like optional commentary bubbles you can click to get a behind the scenes "making of" type view of the game. There are also achievements for every level. Only thing that bothers me about the achievements is some of them are vague and it won't tell you how you can accomplish it (I can't get make it rain or guns away, and I've tried things that make sense to me like throwing money out the window, or shooting out windows. Very frustrating)

Best Game on Quest so far

After a year and about 15 games (many I've sent back) this is the most fun I've had on the Quest. Firstly, I've found I don't really like novelty games like Beat Saber - I prefer ones where you're transported to a different world. This one is a '60s spy thriller and basically comprises a number of escape rooms. They're pitched at just the right level: neither too hard or too easy. A couple of times I laughed out loud at having missed an obvious solution to a problem. A very slight drawback is you can't save where you get up to in a particular adventure which means every time you get killed (which is very often) you have to go back to the start. It usually only takes a minute to get back to where you left off but it can be a bit boring going through it twenty times in one sitting. It's also a bit on the short side - it lasted me a week. But that's part of the nature of this kind of game - unlike a shoot 'em up which you can play over years, once you've finished it it's pretty much ended. But apart from these slight niggles, a brilliant game

OtherbitsMay 23 at 5:23 PM
Dying in a puzzle game?

There's a lot to love about this game. The object interactions, the production values, the humour, its a wonderful experience. One of the best on the Quest.

That said, I hate the dying mechanic. I know its rather central to the whole theme, but it really brings the entire experience down. Its not like it happens rarely either. You'll often be in the middle of solving a rather entertaining puzzle, and suddenly you're thrown a complete curveball and given 4 seconds to solve it. I could almost never think that fast, and would die. This removes all tension and immersion from the level, and is incredibly frustrating because the level now needs to be replayed from the very beginning. If it happens several times, you'll quickly tire of listening to the same dialog and solving the same puzzles over and over. The game only gets away with it because the levels are so short and simple, but that just leads to another problem - the levels are too short and simple.

Its still definitely an experience worthy of your time, but I can't help feeling it would have been so much better if they committed more to the escape room style and made the levels a little longer, made the puzzles a little harder, and made the dying much less frequent, if at all

Alexl342Feb 20 at 5:19 AM
Cant Stop Playing!

This game is a unique and fun attempt at puzzle games. Its premise is simple: youre trapped in an area, and theres a bunch of seemingly useless stuff in there to let you escape. Try not to die. I was on my toes throughout my entire playthrough, because the first thing you think when you spawn in is: Im gonna die. All the levels can be completed in under 3 minutes, but when you finally find out how to beat a level, hours have passed. The game is rewarding in a painful way. Whenever you complete challenges, you get new things in your office to play with. All of them were decently fair and simple to complete (except when you have to flashbang the plane, that was just cruel). Overall I had a great time playing this game. Definitely recommend it to anyone, wether theyre a veteran to VR or a brand new player, anyone can enjoy it.

unqDec 7 at 1:11 AM
This intro!

Intro of this game is the best thing I have seen in VR. Wow! I'm astonished. And not only with this intro.
The whole game is super polished. Everything works smooth, and natural. I really enjoyed playing it and playing with it. Now, let's point some facts:

1. You play the whole game in sitting position. This is nice change in VR games world. You can just sit down, play with some staff, and rest.

2 You are sitting, but you can interact with things on a distance. For example you can pull some things just to catch them and play with them around. And there is a lot of things created just to play around.

3. The whole game is like escape rooms with no math or complicated analysis involved. I found it challenging and relaxing at the same time (usually there is no time pressure).

4. After you finish a level there is still replayability value: each level has achievements and you need to play with those levels a lot to unlock them all.

5. If I count correctly there are 6 levels. The variety of locations is impressive in my opinion (even if many items are reused in each level): there is a plane, a train, a space station, etc. Each of them is unique in the context of puzzles.

6. The theme is very solid, there is no plot, but everything is connected and consistent. It's a spy theme with a lot of humour. And everyone likes spy themes ...and humour. So stop reading this and buy the game already.

7. I'm not the guy, who gives 5 stars easly, but this game couldn't be better. I find not a single element I would like to change. Ok, maybe those scorpions. I hate scorpions. And bees. I hate scorpions and bees. But I love everything else in this game. And I think you will love it too (excluding scorpions) if you buy the game already.

8. Seriously, you could already play this game. Why bother in reading this? You need to finish everything you started, right? I bet you will listen all messages on Dr. Zor's voicemail, when you find it. There is a ton of messages there, because Dr. Zor is too busy doing staff for your attention. Seriously, who recorded all of those? ...you can check by yourself, because there is also a commentary mode in this game (after you finish it). But you need to buy the game first, and reading this is not helping you anymore.

9. I could write more, but I want you to buy this game already.

Do it.

ApeSlaveJan 1 at 8:20 PM
Worth the money, but missed it's shot.

Throughout the game there are many awesome moments worth going back and redoing. The diversity between each level and environment makes them feel very unique and exciting to explore. The graphics are good enough and its not uncomfortable action. But unfortunately the moments that you want the most end up being lazily done. Mainly the ending of every mission. The moment that is the most important which is the accomplishment of the task that you just worked so hard to achieve, is diminished by the lack of effort put into it.

For example. During one mission after you complete it successfully you are launched in a chair as an escape. Instead of it having you lift up and out into the air letting you get a view of the escape it just starts to go black and that's it, back to the headquarters. These moments are the moments that they left out that would make the game extra special. There are lazy things done in this game like this that disappoint me so much I can't give it five stars. If you want to be the best out there you have to put that extra effort in.

But that all being said. Definitely worth the buy.
Have fun!

RyanPiezoDec 24 at 3:16 PM
Excellent game with questionable design

This game is a lot of fun and one of my go tos when showing off my quest to family and friends. The levels are challenging without being obnoxious and the individual puzzles really make you feel like you've accomplished something when you figure them out. There are also multiple ways to solve different puzzles. However, the game seems poorly optimized for the quest as it does crash more often than I would like. There are also some annoying design choices. For example, if you die in the level, you start over from the beginning with the narrator saying the same things over and over. I understand starting the level over from the beginning, but the constant loop of narration when you are trying to figure out a puzzle three quarters of the way through the level is infuriating.

Overall though, excellent game and highly recommended for anybody looking to add to their quest library.

The Ideal VR Puzzle Game

"I Expect You To Die" is an outstanding puzzle game. Despite the low number of 6 levels, the game starts with an easy first level and each level gets slightly more difficult, and takes more time to figure out than the previous one.

The narration is both comedic and serious, and gives slight tips and hints that aren't always necessary, but still helpful. I also like the replayablility of the levels, so that you can earn more achievements by going back to a previous level to complete it in under 2 minutes or so.

You can definitely tell that the developers went for quality over quantity, seeing as how detailed the layout of the levels are and how the backgrounds have effort put into them as well. Even the story and narrations are done flawlessly!

I can't wait for the seventh level to come out later this year, and I hope to see even more in the future!
